ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It's a comprehensive introduction to the field of cryptography, both theoretical and applied, and would be useful to anyone the least bit interested in data security (which, if you're planning on a career in computer science, you should be). You'll learn some number theory along the way and get to talk about things like Quadratic Residuosity, Euler's Totient Function, and the Jacobi Symbol, which will impress your friends. Though there's a lot of material covered in class, the workload isn't bad, and the exams are easier than the problem sets (which themselves aren't terribly difficult, just somewhat time-consuming). Take it!

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Cryptography is hugely important in CS. I feel that I understand crypto concepts well enough now to at least discuss them intelligently, and my breadth of understanding of the field is such that if I need to add crypto to an existing system, I'll have a pretty good idea of where to start and what pitfalls I should look out for along the way.
